comments.body: `EitherLike` scares me, can we not just pass in a function `e -> Either TL.Text Int32`?
or even better, just fmap at the usesite. and pass in `Maybe (Either TL.Text Int32)` here.

Or make a custom typeclass with a method `e -> Either TL.Text Int32` and convert to that if you really don’t want to pass this explicitly. You can still derive the implementation using generics but at least you don’t leak 5 unused type variables to every use site.
I went with the last suggestion. Thanks for pushing me to improve this.

+decodeInternableStrings strs id
+    | V.null strs = lookupStringList id
+    | id == 0 = pure $ map decodeString (V.toList strs)
+    | otherwise = throwError $ ParseError "items and interned id both set for string list"

This doesn't work since
```
EQUAL_DECIMAL : Decimal -> Decimal -> Bool
```
but
```
EQUAL_NUMERIC : forall (n : Nat). Numeric n -> Numeric n -> Bool
```
Similar issues below.
fixed. Thanks for the help

comments.body: Let's use `error` here instead and leave the `pure` at the top. All of this is sitting behind a checker which should make sure we never hit this case anyway.
I just remove the "new" builtins from the proto (We will add builtins, once we exactly know the ones we need).  Then I can put back the `pure` at the top, without using `error` .

comments.body: Why not just call this `Decode`? Together with `MonadDecode` this would fit `mtl`'s `X` vs `MonadX` naming scheme.

`MonadDecode` reflects only `Decode`, not this one (which also includes `MonadReader PackageRefCtx`). Also, `Decode` is in the public interface, whereas the additional elements of `DecodeImpl` are not.
